24797277.projn: IN-Power System Development Project IV -- P101653
24797277.theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
India - Fourth Power System Development
            Project Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Power System Development
            Project and its Additional Financing Project for India
            received a satisfactory outcome rating with low or
            negligible risk to development outcome. Both the Bank and
            the Borrower received satisfactory performance ratings.
            There was one restructuring that took place during this
            project. The restructuring was triggered by the significant
            savings surplus. Additional Financing (PSDP IV AF resulting
            from the combined effects of a highly competitive market,
            the continuing devaluation of the Indian rupee (INR) against
            the U.S. dollar since loan approval, and the regulatory
            requirements to maintain a debt-equity ratio of 70:30 for
            all the schemes financed by Power Grid Corporation of India
            Limited (POWERGRID). Further, in addition to inclusion of a
            new scheme, another scheme was shifted (originally approved
            at appraisal) from the Fifth Power Sector Development
            Project (PSDP V) to PSDP IV AF to leverage the flexibility
            in the POWERGRID portfolio that had the same PDO and KPIs to
            optimally utilize available funds across its various
            engagements. There are several main lessons learned from
            this project and are as follows: (1) Long-term programmatic
            engagement results in a successful partnership. (2) Repeater
            projects contributed toward effective implementation of
            POWERGRID projects. (3) Retroactive financing enabled an
            advance preparation of the project. (4) Strong and reliable
            National Grid is facilitating economic development. (5)
            POWERGRID is now a partner of choice. Over the years,
            POWERGRID has transformed into an organization successfully
            foraying into advanced technologies that it has become a
            partner of choice by Indian states as well as neighboring
            countries. (6) Timely measures required for overcoming Right
            of Way (RoW) issues. It is important to note that given the
            scarcity of resources within the country, RoW has become
            very difficult to obtain. (7) Due focus on safeguards help
            in obtaining forest clearance with a shorter turnaround
            time. (8) Adequate handling of land acquisition issues. The
            land acquisition procedures/laws are too cumbersome. These
            might be counterproductive to sector development and to
            network expansion. (9) Review and updating of procurement
            documents to promote new technologies. As part of this loan
            and in line with the Banks procedures, procurement for some
            of the unique and emerging technologies in India was carried
            out. (10) Vendor conferences resulted in higher
            participation and competitive prices. (11) Restructuring of
            loans to optimize utilization. (12) With large size of
            package, it is useful to have higher prior review threshold.
            (13) Engagement with a capable borrower results in mutual
            learning. Both the Bank and POWERGRID learned from each
            other during this partnership.
